section.title: IAX
section.simpara: IAX Here, we are always referring to IAX2, or IAX version 2. is the Inter-Asterisk-eXchange protocol. This is the Asterisk-native and preferred protocol.

section.title: Why IAX?
section.simpara: Does the world really need yet another VoIP protocol, when we already have SIP, H.323, MGCP and an array of proprietary protocols? Of course, this point remains arguable. Nevertheless, IAX has certain advantages:

listitem.simpara: Minimal overhead: Compared with SIP (and the RTP encapsulated within it), IAX has, as a purely UDP protocol, a significantly better payload-overhead ratio.

NAT/firewall friendly: This is perhaps its biggest advantage -- IAX, because it uses only a single port, is easy to accommodate in firewall rulesets (in the case of SIP, this is at a minimum three, often large port ranges).
Simplicity: There is no need to parse strings, which makes IAX inherently less vulnerable to buffer overflow security flaws.
Call routing and transfer: Calls can be patched by a central server or connected directly between two users.

listitem.para: Trunking. Allows multiple calls to be passed through a single IAX connection, minimizing overhead (see ).

section.title: Example of an IAX configuration
section.simpara: The IAX configuration file iax.conf always begins with the section heading [general]. Just as with sip.conf, [general] contains global parameters which apply to all the individual IAX connections which follow.
To demonstrate the possibilities offered by the IAX protocol, we will connect two IAX PBX systems. In this way, calls can be routed directly between them without need for using the PSTN.

section.title: Objectives
section.simpara: There are two Asterisk systems, named ast1 and ast2, each with two telephones (1000 and 1001). Each system must be able to connect calls to the other via IAX. For this purpose we assign a dialing prefix to each server; 0901 connects calls to ast1 and 0902 connects calls to ast2. The ast1 system has the IP 192.168.0.101 and ast2 has IP 192.168.0.102.

section.title: Configuration of ast1
section.para: The iax.conf for ast1 contains the following configuration: [ast2] type = friend host = 192.168.0.102 secret = 1234 context = test-telephones permit = 0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0The file extensions.conf contains this configuration: [via-asterisk2] exten => 09021000,1,Dial(IAX2/ast2/1000) exten => 09021001,1,Dial(IAX2/ast2/1001) ; ^ ^ ^ ^ ; | | | | ; virt.prefix ext connection ext

section.title: Configuration of ast2
section.para: The iax.conf for ast2 contains the following configuration: [ast1] type = friend host = 192.168.0.101 secret = 1234 context = test-telephones permit = 0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0 The file extensions.conf contains this configuration: [via-asterisk1] exten => 09011000,1,Dial(IAX2/ast1/1000) exten => 09011001,1,Dial(IAX2/ast1/1001)

ToS (or "Type of Service"); sets flags in the IP header which are used for prioritizing traffic in network routers and switches. This is so that time-sensitive traffic can be transmitted before other data. The recommended setting for IAX is tos=ef. EF means "Expedited Forwarding"; this seeks reduced latency, reduced loss rate, and low jitter. The default is none (for backwards compatibility).

The large number of allowed values and flags will not be described here. If you want to read further, have a look at the specifications for differentiated services in RFC 2474 and the IANA-DSCP http://www.iana.org/assignments/dscp-registry registry. For convenience, here is an excerpt from the Asterisk doc file doc/ip-tos.txt (1.4):

blockquote.simpara: * IAX2 ------ In iax.conf, there is a "tos" parameter that sets the global default TOS for IAX packets generated by chan_iax2. Since IAX connections combine signalling, audio, and video into one UDP stream, it is not possible to set the TOS separately for the different types of traffic. In iaxprov.conf, there is a "tos" parameter that tells the IAXy what TOS to set on packets it generates. As with the parameter in iax.conf, IAX packets generated by an IAXy cannot have different TOS settings based upon the type of packet. However different IAXy devices can have different TOS settings. The allowable values for any of the tos* parameters are: CS0, CS1, CS2, CS3, CS4, CS5, CS6, CS7, AF11, AF12, AF13, AF21, AF22, AF23, AF31, AF32, AF33, AF41, AF42, AF43 and ef (expedited forwarding), The tos* parameters also take numeric values. The lowdelay, throughput, reliability, mincost, and none values are deprecated because they set the IP TOS using the outdated "IP precedence" model as defined in RFC 791 and RFC 1349. They still work in this version of Asterisk, but will be removed in future releases. =========================================== Configuration Parameter Recommended File Setting ------------------------------------------- sip.conf tos_sip cs3 sip.conf tos_audio ef sip.conf tos_video af41 ------------------------------------------- iax.conf tos ef ------------------------------------------- iaxprov.conf tos ef ===========================================

To make truly effective use of "quality of service" (QoS), you must ensure that your network hardware supports it and it is activated on your network. For Cisco network hardware, see the "Enterprise QoS Solution Reference Network Design Guide" http://www.cisco.com/application/pdf/en/us/guest/netsol/ns432/c649/ccmigration_09186a008049b062.pdf , for Linux systems see the "Linux Advanced Routing & Traffic Control HowTo" http://www.lartc.org/ .

permit and deny allow and limit the IP addresses which are allowed to connect to this channel. As a matter of good practice, this starts with a deny=0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0 (block all), and then the trusted IP addresses are explicitly allowed with permit statements. Order is significant, and both deny and permit may appear multiple times. If only a single host is intended, you may omit the netmask (which would be 255.255.255.255).
section.para: This example allows only connections from 192.168.0.* (netmask 24 bits, class C):deny = 0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0 ; deny all permit = 192.168.0.102/255.255.255.0 ; allow 192.168.0.* permit = 192.168.5.5 ; allow 192.168.5.5

The following example does not make any sense, since it begins by denying 192.168.0.0 - 192.168.0.127, but then allows everyone, which supersedes the initial deny rule. In this case, nothing is denied:deny = 192.168.0.0/255.255.255.127 permit = 0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0 ; alle erlauben

It is typically the job of the device to implement a jitter buffer Jitter refers to variable latency of packets in a data stream. If the variability is too great, it can cause dropouts or artifacts in the resulting audio. . In the event the remote device has a poorly-functioning jitter buffer, you can use Asterisk as a VoIP bridge and use Asterisk's jitter buffer.

The resynchronization threshold is the sum of the measured variance and the value of resyncthreshold, given in milliseconds.
